Review Title: Expansive and stunning, this botanical garden boasts a vast, diverse collection of plants
Review Text: We visited the Royal Botanical Gardens in Kandy, a sprawling 147-acre expanse that dates back to the 14th century, though its formal establishment was in 1821. We only had time to explore a small portion, perhaps two or three acres, but were captivated by its beauty. The gardens are world-renowned for their extensive collection of over 4,000 plant species, including a magnificent orchid house, spices, medicinal plants, and imposing palm avenues. A unique feature is the tradition of visiting dignitaries planting memorial trees; one notable example is the Ceylon ironwood tree planted by Tsar Nicholas II of Russia during his visit in 1891.

Review Text: This massive garden was a joy to explore on a hot day as it was much cooler under the trees. There's a nice children education center that includes a whimsical maze area including a bunny hedgehog and more. Plan to spend time here.

Review Title: A Peaceful Nature Escape Near Kandy
Review Text: Just 15 minutes from Kandy city, the Royal Botanic Gardens, Peradeniya is a must-visit for anyone who loves nature, photography, or simply a peaceful stroll. The gardens are huge and beautifully maintained, with over 4,000 plant species from around the world. My favourites were the colourful Orchid House, the impressive avenue of Royal Palms, and the massive Javan fig tree which is truly a wonder to see. It’s a very calm and relaxing place, with plenty of benches to sit and take in the scenery. You can easily spend 2–3 hours wandering here. Tip: Visit in the morning or late afternoon for softer light and fewer crowds. Wear comfortable shoes as the gardens are quite big, and bring your camera — every corner is a photo opportunity!

The origins of the Botanic Gardens date as far back as 1371 when King Wickramabahu III ascended the throne and kept court at Peradeniya near the Mahaweli river. This was followed by King Kirti Sri and King Rajadhi Rajasinghe. A temple was built on this location by King Wimala Dharma, but it was destroyed by the British when they were given control over the Kingdom of Kandy.[citation needed] Thereafter, the groundwork for a botanical garden was formed by Alexandar Moon in 1821. He used the garden for coffee and cinnamon plants.[4] The Botanical Garden at Peradeniya was formally established in 1843 with plants brought from Kew Garden, Slave Island, Colombo, and the Kalutara Garden in Kalutara. The Royal Botanic Garden, Peradeniya was made more independent and expanded under George Gardner as superintendent in 1844. On Gardner's death in 1849 George Henry Kendrick Thwaites became superintendent. He served until he resigned in 1879, when he was succeeded by Henry Trimen, who served until 1895.[5][6] He was succeeded in turn by John Christopher Willis who served as director from 1898 until 1912. The garden came under the administration of the Department of Agriculture when it was established in 1912. There are avenues in the River Drive such as Cook's Pine Avenue, Palmyra Palm Avenue, Double Coconut Avenue, Cabbage Palm Avenue, and Royal Palm Avenue.[7] The classical Avenue of Palms is in this Garden. One item with a significant history is the Cannonball Tree planted by King George V of the United Kingdom and Queen Mary in 1901. It is often load with fruit, which are thought to resemble cannonballs. During World War II, the Botanic Garden was used by Lord Louis Mountbatten, the supreme commander of the allied forces in the South Asia, as the headquarters of the South East Asia Command. The gardens were used as a location in the 1957 film The Bridge on the River Kwai. Great excursion. Very relaxing and interesting tour - saw a lot in an hour. Lots of different specimens and some lovely landscaping.

We visited Peradeniya Botanical Gardens in April with our family, and it was truly one of the highlights of our trip to Kandy. The gardens are vast, beautifully maintained, and offer a perfect blend of natural beauty and tranquility. Walking through the towering palm avenues, orchid house, and spice gardens was a relaxing and enriching experience. The sheer variety of flora was impressive, and the kids especially enjoyed the giant bamboo and the massive Javan fig tree. The weather in April was warm but pleasant, and there were plenty of shaded areas to rest. We packed some snacks and had a lovely little picnic on the grass. It’s also a great spot for photography—every corner has something unique to offer. Highly recommend this place for families, nature lovers, or anyone looking to spend a peaceful day outdoors. Give yourself at least 2–3 hours to explore fully. Tip: Wear comfortable shoes, bring water, and try to visit early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the midday heat.

The gardens are perfectly maintained, being Sunday they met so many families who played, couples walking. The park has trees from all over the world, monkeys, orchids, a small spice garden, many colorful flower beds and towards the bottom of the park a natural spectacle: thousands of flying foxes!! Absolutely recommended

Explanatory stands with interesting information have been set up. They give you a map at the entrance. We've had some bad luck with the weather, but on a sunny day it should be really nice.

I was so impressed at every turn. This is a place not be missed. There are so many exotic species, endemic , native, and toxic species all color coded. I found wandering the outside regions instead of the orchid house more interesting personally. They had a large collection of cacti and succulents and incredible old huge trees. AN umbrella or at least a sun hat was important when we went. We had a trolley drive and stop so that we were able to cover more of the park. This is a wonderful place to spend several hours.
It's a real joy to have this breath of oxygen and greenery after the tumult of Kandi. Not the most flowery period but the trees are exceptional

This was day three of our stay in Sri Lanka and what a way to start the set of excursions we had planned. We had no idea how amazing this set of gardens were going to be. The plants, trees, colours, shrubs were simply stunning in colour. We walked for about 2.5 hours and could easily have been there for longer. Our guide walked with us and told us of the tradition for the benches in the park where ladies sit and meet their male partners or meet a male partner. It was so lovely to see so many young couples sitting and starting out on their life’s journey. Lord Mountbatten’s World War II residence is in the grounds as is the famous tree shown in the film The Bridge Over the River Kwai. We finished up at one of the cares with cold ginger beers and lemonade’s. What an amazing place and one you must see if you are in Kandy.

If you like your botany with a side order of Colonial history, and movie trivia, Kandy Botanical Gardens will suit you down to the ground! These gardens, a former Royal Garden dating back to the 14th century, are beautifully laid out but not in an overly formal style. The British turned it into a Botanical Garden in the19th century. A highlight of the visit was a guided tour led by Mr Bandara Palipana, the lead academic for the gardens and author of numerous books on the gardens and the flora of Sri Lanka (he will happily sell you one from a bundle he carries around with him!). Mr Palipana, a distinguished,older gentleman, full of anecdotes, took us on a tour of superlatives, showing us the oldest, biggest, most poisonous, most important, most beautiful, most beneficial, trees and plants. He also regaled us with tales of Royal visits by HM Queen Elizabeth and Lord Mountbatten who lived in a bungalow in the grounds, and the garden's role in the movie 'Bridge Over The River Kwai'. All in all, an absolute treat!.

The Royal Botanic Gardens at Peradeniya was established in 1821, six years after the final occupation of the Kandyan Kingdom by the English. The site is less than 5.5 Km from Kandy on the Colombo Road, and occupies a loop of the river Mahaweli, which surrounds it on all sides except the south, where it is bounded by the main road. The area 61.25 ha in extent, is about 1550ft from sea level. More than 4000 species of plants including woody trees, Palms, Ferns, Orchids and shrubs currently present within the gardens.

Peradeniya Botanical Garden is a must-visit for nature lovers. The sprawling grounds are filled with historical trees, stunning flowers, and inviting lawns. While the entry fee for foreigners (3000 LKR) is significantly higher than for locals (200 LKR), the experience is well worth it. Just be mindful of the monkeys that can be found in certain areas and take necessary precautions to avoid any unwanted encounters. Overall, Peradeniya Botanical Garden offers a peaceful and enchanting escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Botanical Gardens of Peradeniya - 147 acres in extent, this is the best and the largest garden in Sri Lanka that a visitor to Kandy should never miss. Created in the 14th Century as the Pleasure Garden of Kandyan Kings, the Royal Botanical Gardens of Peradeniya is surrounded by the river Mahaweli on three sides and is connected to the opposite bank by a suspension bridge. With more than 4000 species of flora, the garden is an example of the wealth and beauty of the tropics. With more than hundred varieties of palm trees, five palm avenues where palms such as Talipot grow to an immense size, wonderful arches of glossy foliage, lovely fernery, and orchid houses with rare blossoms and spice trees in groves make it a rich botanical heritage in the world.

As a seasoned tour guide with over a decade of experience in showcasing the best of Sri Lanka, the Peradeniya Botanical Garden remains one of my favorite places to take visitors. This sprawling garden, nestled near Kandy, is a haven for nature lovers and offers a unique glimpse into the island’s rich botanical heritage.

Review Text: Tourism in Sri Lanka is being affected by a disappointing two-tier system that shows no respect for foreign visitors at attractions, 3000rs for foreigners and a fraction of the price for locals. This problem is reflected in the declining number of returning tourists. Despite having visited the country many times over the last 13 years with my Sri Lankan wife and her family, I have not seen any improvement in this situation, only a rise in costs. Peradeniya Botanical Garden is a must-visit destination for nature enthusiasts and anyone seeking tranquility amidst lush greenery. Walking through its sprawling grounds, you're greeted with a mesmerizing array of exotic plants and trees from around the world. The meticulously curated pathways lead you on a journey through different ecosystems, from towering palm trees to vibrant orchid displays. One of the highlights is the majestic avenue of royal palms, a breathtaking sight that evokes a sense of grandeur. The variety of flora is astounding, with each section offering something new to discover. The orchid house is a particular delight, showcasing rare and colorful blooms in a serene setting. Beyond its botanical wonders, Peradeniya Botanical Garden offers a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of everyday life. Whether you're strolling along the tranquil riverbanks or picnicking beneath the shade of ancient trees, there's a sense of serenity that envelops you. The garden is well-maintained, and the staff are friendly and knowledgeable, eager to share insights about the plants and their origins. Additionally, the visitor facilities are clean and convenient, making for a pleasant overall experience. Overall, Peradeniya Botanical Garden is a true gem, offering a harmonious blend of natural beauty and relaxation. Whether you're a nature lover, a photographer, or simply looking for a peaceful retreat, this botanical paradise is sure to leave a lasting impression.

A rally lovely & relaxing place to visit with many areas to enjoy throughout the gardens, some fabulous views to enjoy. A lot of history too, to absorb. The variety & care taken for the upkeep is first rate. Ensure you allow yourself the time to properly enjoy this place. Views from the suspension bridge are fantastic as well as interesting engineering construction.

We had a very enjoyable visit to the Royal Botanic Gardens. Kandy City can be noisy and quite polluted, so it was nice to get away to the gardens for some peace and clean air. The gardens are beautifully maintained and have a very relaxed feel. You are provided with a good map when you get your tickets and that is very useful to plan your route. Most impressive are probably the coconut palms. At the far end of the garden there is a wobbly suspension bridge out over the Mahaweli River, which is worth a walk on! There are also a large number of trees around the Great Circle planted by world leaders and royalty over the years, which is nice to see. All in all, a good place to spend a couple of hours.

Restaurant on site we didn't try but the shop next to it selling drinks and snacks was really good value considering we were a captive audience. Probably our best value day in Kandy and quite possibly my favourite attraction. Highly recommended

An unmissable visit, these gardens are a true marvel! They are located a few kilometers from Kandy, easily reachable by bus or tuk tuk. Entrance price 3000 rupees Huge park, where you can spend no less than 3 hours walking among hundreds of species of tropical plants. The pearl is the orchid greenhouse, where you can admire wonderful flowers.
Very clean and well-kept, extremely spacious and large. Lots of plants and tree species, some animals We were here for 2 hours and it was enough. Not a must but possible :)
Botanical Gardens outside Kandy. Not very well looked after, very large and with lots of plants. Worth a visit if you have time to spare.

What a a relaxed balance compared to busy and loud Kandy and for a reasonable entrance fee. We really loved the big flowering trees and the giant bamboo by the river.  Also the hanging bridge was nice. We spend a good 3 hours here and liked the calm ambience.

Entrance requires ticket - it is not free! Expected well-maintained garden having visited botanical gardens in other countries, especially since a fee is charged for entrance but disappointed. Oh, was shocked that there were trees full of bats. There must have been hundreds of them. Super shocked at the sight. We left soon after.

Lovely gardens, very well maintained, enjoyable few hours, worth going to have a wander (a few monkey's there too). We stayed at Hanthana House just outside of Kandy which was fabulous and their driver took us on a tour of Kandy which included here.
Nice place for walking and for those who are addicted to the nature. We spend 3 hours there and the place was amazing
kandy at its best nicely maintained one of the best places to visit for nature lovers. the restaurants need more quality & bit over priced for foreigners. have a paid buggy tour

Amazing. Equal to, if not better than Singapore botanical gardens. Great collection. Nearly all plants have a plaque to explain origin, name etc. Beautifully maintained. Definitely worth the time and effort to stroll around
So Green. Beautiful gardens. Instead of feeding squirrels we found ourselves spotting chipmunks and feeding monkeys! Great water features and plenty of plants (including giant bamboo) to get lost in.

A lovely afternoon visit to the gardens. They are very spacious and have particularly interesting sections including the cycads, giant bamboo, cabbage palm Avenue and orchid house. Wish we had take a picnic, as the vibe would be perfect to sit and relax for an afternoon in the sun. There is a small cafe with a limited selection and clean toilets. Also a discount on entry to students (foreign).
Very beautiful & well maintained gardens, not too busy, with a large variety of plants, trees & flowers

This was not on my list of places to visit but my guide enquired so I went for it and it was so enjoyable that I spent nearly 3 hours inside. Lots of amazing trees and flowering plants. Many different spaces and amazing landscape. Definitely worth the visit!
I recently visited the Royal Botanical Gardens. What a great experience w. The gardens are extensive and was so relaxing to walk around.

Really beautiful gardens and reasonable entry fee. Easy to spend a couple of hours wandering around the beautiful place and plenty of shady benches to relax. Down the top end there are trees full of huge bags too which was amazing to see.

We hired a tuk-tuk to take us on the three-temple-loop and then to the Botanical Gardens:  It took much longer than we expected to drive out to the temples however 2 of the 3 were quite worthwhile: Ancient and interesting.  The Botanical Gardens however was a disappointment:  It is a large, well-tended park.  A nice park, but just a park that has some name signs on trees and shrubs.

We loved the botanical gardens. It's beautiful, lots of open space as well as different themed houses. The orchid house was really nice. There's monkeys towards to back near the bamboo which were really cute to see. There's a little shop just outside for snacks and drinks. We spent 1.5 hours in the gardens but could have easily done longer. Lots of shaded areas to get out the sun.

well maintained garden. lots of big trees and plants. its a very good place to be with your family for a rest. huge ground areas for kids to play. have few places to buy some snacks also. overall good place and should visit it 7/10 recommended!

Ok but not great. There are many huge trees, but not enough flowers or colorful shrubs imo. The place is big enough for kids to run around. But they mainly liked the squirrels and monkeys that we found, trees did not catch our attention too much mostly.

A well maintained garden , this place was a pleasure to visit and a nice break from the hustle and bustle of town. We spent only 2 hours there but you could easily wander around longer. Plenty of paths and open space, information boards etc. The Plant House and Orchid House were the favourites as they were of interests to us; with many similar plants in our home. Another big tick for this garden is the section where world leaders had planted a tree and we could see how much the tree has grown from then.... A recommended visit !

You don't have to be a dedicated gardener to enjoy these gardens. Trees are labelled according to whether they're native, imports, even poisonous- so don't lick these ones! We had our guide with us, and he had a lot of knowledge about some of the plants and trees, that we may have missed if we'd been by ourselves. The mahogany trees are spectacular- the root system is about a metre high. The Cannonball tree looks like it has coconuts, but they weigh about 4kg. The palm trees lining one path are huge, and the little ones in between them are the same type, but look different when they're younger. We saw flying foxes, a water monitor, birdlife, and there's an orchid house, and a small suspension bridge. We were here a few hours, and it was a very pleasant visit. Well recommended.
superb gardens. very neat and clean and lots of walking paths. the views are pictuesque and the feel is very good. must visit place

This centuries old botanical garden planned by the British in the centre of the hill station Kandy, Sri Lanka is huge. There are a number of covered exhibits category wise like seasonal flowers, cactus, perennial et al., The place is well maintained and the pathways are clean. A number of families picnicking in the park are also mindful of the trash they generate and are meticulous in keeping the area clean. There are a number of species of plants and trees which are imported from across the world and are thriving in the botanical garden. One needs atleast a couple of hours to walk around the garden and enjoy the nature. The entry fee to the garden is reasonable and the park is secured fully by barbed wire fencing. The security checks at the entrance are robust. Take your camera along. Recommended.

The nicest and most relaxing thing to do I Kandy. So many trees, plants and fauna from all around the world. Some very large trees and bamboo. Fruit bats roosting in the tree tops, monkeys and birds to see.

We stopped for a quick visit on our way to Nuwara Eliya but ended up staying for two hours in there because it is so beautiful and enormous. It is very relaxing to walk around or sit for a picnic. Huge collection of plants from all over the world and large trees that are more than 50 years old. Highly recommended if you are staying in Kandy or just passing by!
Actually in Kandy no more places to visit, this Park is the main place in the to, so if you are tourist you have to visit it. It has all kind of plan
Amazing to see all the different types of trees and plants. Nice walk, plenty of shade to keep you cool

Fabulous botanical gardens, very well maintained and a must see when visiting Kandy. The variety of trees, plants and fauna are amazing, we followed the path along the river and came to the suspension bridge at the top, then made our way back towards the orchid house. Approx an hour and a half.
These gardens are a must see in Kandy - they are absolutely beautiful...the flying fox bats by the river were spectacular...
If you're travelling to Kandy, visiting these gardens is a must. They are beautiful. A nature-lovers dream.
Great place to explore with kids. Nature at it’s best. Well maintained park with lush green park for children to play and explore different plants.

Peradeniya Royal Botanical Garden is located few kilometers away from Kandy city Sri Lanka. This ancient flower garden is home to authentic fauna and floras. You can get ralaxe at this calm environment.

Went at 9am to avoid the crowds although the temperature was low 30's. Great shaded walkways. Well laid out, easy to follow on the given map. Tree signage brilliant with signage making you aware of the poisoness trees and who planted what. Don't miss it if you visit Kandy.

Beautiful gardens, very well kept, not cheap tickets, but worth the price if you are interested in trees, that are the main attraction. The orchid glasshouse was a bit of a delusion because there weren’t any particular varieties.
Excellently maintained gardens and Orchid House. Leisurely stroll around the stunning flora. Helps to have a knowledgeable guide but not a necessity. Must see when visiting the area.

Peradeniya Royal Botanical Garden is a must-visit place in Kandy. It is an elegantly landscaped garden with palm tree avenues, pine avenues, and flower beds. The Orchid House is quite beautiful with lots of colorful blooms.

Quite expensive to enter for a Sri Lankan attraction, 2000 rupees per person for foreigners. But it is worth it. The grounds are extensive with beautiful trees, palms, shrubs, flowers, a lake etc. You will spend several hours walking around the various paths, sit down and appreciate some views, a very restful relaxing place contrasting with the hustle and bustle of Kandy itself.
Had a good walk through the gardens. There are several unique plants in the garden. The orchids were OK but there were not as many that I heard about.

This is a very large, well maintained garden with lots to see as you wander around. You’ll need at least a couple of hours for a quick tour. There is quite a bit of renovation going on so some places are closed. It costs 2000 rupees for foreigners to get in. Street vendors aren’t allowed in so your visit will be relaxed and hassle free. We didn’t visit at the best time of year in terms of flowers, but it was lovely nonetheless.

Peradeniya Botanic Gardens is a unique gift of Mother Nature with its ancient yet beautiful landscape.  This garden will be of great use to biologists, as it is home to a wide variety of species.  It is also a perfect place for family, friends or lovers to relax and unwind on the go with their children.  Even Tulu Latha brings helpful bliss. In particular, the garden is ready to capture your beautiful moments and create beautiful views by looking around throughout the garden. No matter how reluctant you are to leave again with the freedom you enjoy throughout the park, you will have to limit your leisure activities to 5 pm whenever you enter the park grounds.

One of the oldest botanical gardens in the world.  Our guide around the gardens was the botanist Bandara Palipana and he made it a most interesting tour.  We saw many trees and shrubs which were new to us and the stories behind some of the plantings was interesting.  The orchis collection has over 300 varieties on show.  The Cook pine (introduced from New Caledonia by Captain Cook) is unusual as always leans towards the equator.   HM Queen Elizabeth II, Lord Mountbatten, King George IV, Yuri Gagarin and others have planted trees there.  Lord Mountbatten used the old residence in the centre f the park as his headquarters as Supreme Allied Commander of South East Asia Command during WWII.  The gardens are kept in a pristine condition.  Many Bollywood films have used it for location shooting.

Absolutely stunning. Words can’t do it justice. A wonderful day away from the noise of the city. Get a tuktuk/bus from Kandy. You won’t regret it - beautifully maintained, informative. Great space to unwind.

We arrived early in the morning and were lucky to get a golf buggy and guide for an additional 1000rps. This helped us cover more than 5km of the beautiful gardens and ensured that we managed to see all the highlights within about an hour. Our guide was lovely! super friendly and informative and gave us good insight into the gardens history and fauna and flora. The entrance fee is 2000rps per person which is very reasonable considering the immaculate condition the garden is kept in. This is a must for nature lovers, photographers and artists!

Lots of plants to see and big walks but a ridiculous price!! 4000 rupees for two British people. Come off it guys! We were so shocked at the price that we even tried to pretend we were both students (I actually am but my partner is not) and they said they wouldn’t accept that and had to pay full price! 4000 for a walk around the garden. It took all the cash we had so we had to get out more. 250 for locals or something. In the UK that would be called racism my friends!!

These gardens were a highlight of our time in candy. The gardens where a peaceful haven from a bustling city centre. There were many distinct areas and a huge variety of different types of trees. We could’ve spent hours and hours there

Great verity of trees, plants and flowers. I could see acres and acres of greenery.  It takes at least a day to see it all. Nice place to relax. Nice place to picnic and enjoy the nature. Nicely kept garden with lost of space. Ideal to take photos. Enjoyed the green houses with verity of cactus, orchids, roses, tropical flowers and ornamental plants. Could see some birds, butterflies and lots of big bats. The Mahavali River runs along side of it giving some vibrancy. Away from the busy town life and noise. Less crowded when I visited and couldn't see any foreign tourists. Could see many rear plants.

Nice place to spend your day with your loved ones. Garden is quite big and well maintained. Easy to find the main route hence signboards are clearly show it. It was my 3rd visit and hope to visit again. Recommend.

Felt in love with these gardens, soo many species of trees and flowers there with little signboards with explanations. A relaxing moment with lots of birds (and  the giant bats that are a bit scary !!) a must see in Kandy, we did love our afternoon there

This garden is wonderful. Due to my healthy situation, I hired a caddy and it was so pleasant and quite to hang out, discovering all those amazing scenographies: the Royal Palm Avenue, the Orchid House, a rubber thee creating a forest all alone (like in the Jungle Book!), a huge selection of different grass samples, a noisy colony of flying foxes (big bats)…Do not miss these garden, walk around and discover yourself your coup de cœur!!
You can easily spend the half day there. The exhibition has a high variety of local and global plants. We absolutely recommend to go there if you have time.

We were there with my family and they were enjoying a lot by playing here and there on the grass. There were lots of historical trees around it and all most every single tree you can find in Sri Lanka you can find a sample here. Ticket will be around $10 and it’s really worth it. There were lots of tourists there and I guess everybody was enjoying there. Loved to return to be back.

We stopped at the botanical gardens after visiting the Temple of the Tooth and it was a lovely way to end the day. The gardens are extensive so be prepared for a lot of walking (in the heat!)! Our guide arranged for a tour of the gardens for us and it was great, we got to see the whole area and the different varieties of plants, learn a little about the history of the gardens, and all without breaking a sweat! Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.

This is a really attractive large park in the town of Kandy, full of wonderful trees, shrubs and plants, many from different parts of the world. Entry is relatively cheap and I would suggest paying a little extra to tour the park with a driver on one of the electric buggies (it is very hot to walk around and explore the whole park - there's a lot to see and the drivers are quite knowledgeable). Most of the trees etc. have descriptive plaques, and you'll notice from the information that many were planted by famous people, some over a hundred years ago. In one area in some fir trees, you'll almost certainly see roosting bats, which was quite a surprise. The Royal Palm avenue is very nice too. Don't miss the Orchid House near the entrance before you leave. Very good.

Went to the gardens with mixed emotions, wasn't too sure I would enjoy it. Wow was I surprised. They are stunning with loads to see. Loved Royal Palm avenue, loved watching the bats flying around in the large fir trees and the orchids were magnificent. Well worth a visit
Beautiful gardens and extensive grounds all immaculately kept .Easy to follow route around main sights and we particularly enjoyed the beautiful orchid house.

it was a hot day but the gardens did not disappoint.  A favorite place for wedding photography we were lucky to see three separate brides and grooms in the short time we were there.  There is a lot to see and a lot we didn't realize was on site. It would pay to do a bit more research before you go so you make effective use of your time. Entrance fee of 1000 KLR pp cash only no credit cards accepted.  This is quite a cheap outing.
Peaceful haven to visit and take time out to walk around all the lovely trees and and plants. Make sure to go into the Orchid House.place of vibrant colours and peace

This is an excellent botanical site. I would suggest allowing a morning or afternoon to undertake a full visit. We benefited from a guide who could tell you about the various trees etc. A visit to the orchid house is a must.

This is a massive garden that is well-maintained with more than 4,000 species of plants, range from humongous trees to herbs, flora, palm trees, orchids, etc. It was built since 14th century as royal  garden, but was destroyed during British occupation and was made as garden for coffee and cinnamons in 19th century. It was then under the administration of Department of Agriculture since 1912 when it was established. Beautiful place to spend for half a day especially for plants lovers. Many sitting benches, people also doing picnic on the lawns. Toilets are available within the park. Many different sections, such as palm tree sections, giant trees, orchid garden, cacti section, flowerbed section, etc. There is a section with interesting sights of lots of visible hanging bats on the tree branches. Overall it was a pleasant and therapeutic session to walk around the garden. Brochure indicates various species of birds can be found in the garden, but we could hardly see any. Also, the entrance fee is rather steep for foreigners at LKR2,000 per person per entry whereas locals only pay a small fraction.
Very nice gardens and very big, they have a lot of different species of plants and flowers. Also a chance to see a lot of birds and other animals. In the trees you can see hundreds of flying foxes
Four of us enjoyed another visit to the excellent gardens but noted that, due to the current Covid-19 problems, the number of visitors were greatly reduced. This made our visit even more personal.

A tranquil place after all the noise from traffic. Lovely gardens, especially the number of different trees. Orchids were good, but a small display, we are used to the orchid garden in Singapore, which I reckon must be the best in the world.

We went to the Botanical Garden a few days ago. We arrived at 8am before it got hot and crowded. We went on an hours buggy ride round the garden which was great as we were shown the main areas and special plants and then we were able to go back to the areas we wanted to see again. The orchid house was lovely and not to be missed.

Visited for an afternoon and was a very pleasant stroll through lovely grounds. Tourists pay 2000rupees and you can hire a golf cart for an extra 2000 if you feel too hot too walk. They have a fantastic selection of trees which are nice and shady to sit under and there is a lovely cool cafeteria where you can sit and have lunch and soft drinks at reasonable prices.

Loved this place! Great relaxing few hours spent here wandering around in theses fabulous gardens. There was lots of wildlife too including peacocks, monkeys and bats! Lots of areas of shade providing a welcome relief from the heat. Do check out the suspension beige too.

Large botanical gardens that are doing great work alongside Kew gardens amongst others. Some great tree species to see from around the world , as well as beautiful flowering plants. Loved the avenue of palms, the large , old mahogony tree and the Madagascan 'canon ball tree' with its beautiful fruits shaped like cannon balls and its beautiful flowers. Well laid out, well sign posted and very well maintained. You will probably need 3 hours plus to see it all. Although there is shade , it was hot walking around so take plenty of water. There is a cafe , ideally located by the large lawn if you want to stay longer/ are in need of refreshments.

Wonderful gardens with all sorts of birds monkeys and large fruit bats. The tour in the golf buggy was wonderful and very welcome if you're a bit dodgy on your pins. The driver was also knowledgeable friendly and amusing. They don't have enough 3 seater buggies so you have to be lucky or pushy to get one. A pity they don't have more benches so that you can just and ponder. Lots of history.

It was a very pleasant and relaxing walk through this large botanical garden seeing so many different species of flowers and trees, as well as endemic vegetation. In hot day you can really enjoy the shade and the tour through alleys of palm trees. Give yourself 3-4 hours.

What a total waste of space and time. The Orchid House and the Rose Garden were totally pointless and disappointing. The local Garden Centre in the UK has a better range of both Orchids and Roses. So we gave up and went to the cafe in the middle was a welcome spot to sit and have a drink. There are virtually no seats in the garden to look and relax.

We didn’t spend enough time here as our driver was picking us up so we didn’t see all the gardens but what we saw was beautiful.  we were amazed at the bats in the trees there were hundreds of them and very noisy! When you come here make sure you bring enough water as its very hot work walking around. Well worth a visit!!
Excellent gardens to walk around, beautiful flowers and lots of information on route. Try the suspension bridge if you have a head for heights and watch your bags with the cheeky wild monkeys

Easy to spend a full afternoon here. Beautiful well kept gardens with lots of interesting trees and plants. There is an orchid house, suspension bridge and fruit bats along with cheeky monkeys who will take  food from your hand. But be warned, they can be slightly aggressive. The cafe is welcoming on a hot day.

FABULOUS. I had a great few hours here. Amazing. The trees etc were spectacular. The cheeky monkeys roaming around watching for an opportunity. Magical place. Well worth a visit. Very well maintained. Sch a variety of things to see. Camera fanatics would love this.
Go and visit this amazing garden if you can. Plants trees orchids palms cycads they are all here to enchant and educate

Lovely place to visit. We only managed to be able to stay a couple of hours but if you can stay longer it is well worth it. Beautiful and clean and plenty of information regarding the plants. Restaurant on site looked lovely but we did not have time to try. Lots of clean toilets too.

Arrived here with our guide and had a lovely walk around the gardens, wild monkeys roam around the gardens and provide some entertainment. There is also a large number of fly foxes who hang out in the trees down by the river who made a really loud squeaking noise. The gardens are beautiful and particularly liked the orchid displays

I was going to sum this place up in 2 words Absolutely Stunning, but TripAdvisor advises I use a minimum of 100  :-) So I'll mention the bats and how lovely it was to see them hanging about. And the suspension bridge, that is narrow and quite scary. Oh and the gardens have a large gift shop. And the Orchid House is amazing. The best part for me though was how they did the Avenue of Trees.  The palm one especially was the most wonderful thing I've seen in a botanical gardens (and I've been to a few in my time)! To summarise, please, please go.  You'll love it.
Am not one for mancured lawns, etc. But this was very impressive!  Orginally designed and run by British gardeners, now under Sri Lankan management, of course, and quite lovely!

The entrance fee is expensive LKR2000 per person. There are many different species of of trees. They are beautifully line-up. There is also a section of plants planted and donated by foreign delegates. A indoor orchids orchard. Beware, there are a few trees full of bat's hanging and flying around. Go early as the sun climbs higher, it can get very hot.

this is one place worth definitely visiting in sri lanka. never i have seen so many different orchids, so many different trees from different continents at one huge place. its is absolutely beautiful and well maintained. take a stroll around the park and enjoy the natural beauty. it is definitely highly recommended to visit this park.takes around 2 hours to go around the park,since the garden is so huge.

The Royal Botanical Garden is a must visit when in Kandy, it is vast and offers plenty of shade on hot days, beautifully kept and looked after. An amazing range of plants and trees and just a very tranquil place to be, make sure to set aside a morning or afternoon as it’s not a quick visit or better still take a picnic and go for the day. Stunning.

A bit west of Kandy in Peradeniya lies this very popular site. It is spread over 147 acres or nearly .6 square kilometers. More than 4,000 species of plants, spices, palm trees and medicinal plants can be found here. It is a place for solitude, especially if you have come from the Temple of the Tooth. There are several avenues of note, including the Avenue of Palms. The Orchid House is visually stunning.

If you have limited time, I would recommend you get the electric buggy around the gardens, for a small extra charge (equivalent to about £1 each).  It's a large site and you get to see a lot of it in the buggy. Other groups had their personal guides with them and got a lot more out of it than we did, as ours didn't come in with us.  But is was pleasant to be taken round and see the different types of flora and fauna.  We also saw the house where Lord Mountbatten stayed during part of the 2nd World War.

A very pleasant few hours strolling around looking at the plants & landscaping. It’s not exactly Q Gardens but interesting. Entry is around £10 & if the suns out it’s very warm. It’s very clean & immaculately maintained. Loved the suspension bridge, although it is very bouncy. Loads of monkeys all around & if you look up there are trees full of very large bats.

After a morning in the crazy streets of Kandy, it was lovely to get away from it all and visit the gardens. They are quite expansive and if you have a problem walking then there is a golf buggy type vehicle that goes around the gardens. I do not know how often they operate but the trip lasts about an hour. Best ask at ticket office. There is a cafe overlooking the expansive lawns about 5 minutes after the entrance and this is a good place to plan your route with the map provided as you enter. The soft drinks were reasonably priced 160 for a  Sprite and the cafe has some very clean bathrooms. The gardens are peaceful and whilst there are many more impressive botanical gardens around the world this is a pleasant way to spend couple of hours.

We were with a small tour group to see the gardens. The gardens are very well designed and have speciality areas for different types of flowers and trees.  Several historical trees have signs indicating who and when the tree was planted. For instance, both Queen Elizabeth and a Russian Astronaut planted trees in this garden   There are monkeys on the property so you should not have food with you while walking.  Also, a restaurant is available on the property.
Very expensive to visit here in off season. Nothing much to see in the month of jan... And not worth...

Huge gardens with a great array of plants and areas to walk. You can organise a drive around the gardens from just inside the gate which will help cover a lot more area of the gardens especially on a hot day.Beautifully maintained and well cared for.

One of our favourite stops during our visit to Sri Lanka, these historic gardens are impressive, and beautifully maintained. Featuring trees, plants and flowers from all over the world, it is a testament to the curiosity of British settlers who first established them (and the to sustained commitment of the Sri Lankan government to preserving the site. Lovely grounds to stroll, with many spots providing cooling shade to escape the often oppressive heat. We spent a few hours roaming, and saw perhaps half of the park. The orchid house is s highlight, as are the tree-lined pathways featuring particular species (double coconuts, royal palms, etc).

My wife and I enjoyed a lovely casual stroll around the gardens on a sunny afternoon. The gardens are amazing with so many different species and variety of plans to see and admire. You can enjoy watching the monkeys play here too there are a lot of them around the trees and you can also see many flying squirrels here too. Well worth going here to chill and take a break.

Very nice botanical garden with beautiful and impressive trees and very nice layout. Just follow the numbers on the map for an excellent walk for several hours. Not so many plants to see and a few flowers this time of the year but still some very fantastic views and a lot of benches and spots just to sit and enjoy the scenery. Bring some food of your own for a picknick as the restaurant is below par compared to the beautiful surroundings.
It's really worth visiting these gardens and don't skimp on time as there's a lot to see. It's beautifully laid out and well signposted.
The gardens are fantastic but... 2000rs for foreigner vs 100rs for Sri Lankan is not ok. I don't mind some price differential, but that is too much

We were initially hesitant about a visit to the royal botanical gardens but overall it is a pleasant visit. We were focussing on a few displays that we were interested in. Firstly we went to see the giant bamboo forest which was amazing. We also went to take a look at the fig tree and the orchid house. It is well maintained but having more flowers would be good.

This is a must do in Kandy. Can easily spend 2-3 hours here just walking around and admiring the nature. Go in the morning as it is cooler and more pleasant to walk around. Do not miss the monkeys, fruit bats and suspension bridge. Really well kept - kudos to the managememt.

This is a must see in Kandy. There is a big variety of plants and what impressed me the most was that not only is the names of the plants/trees shown, but also the country of origin. We spend about 3 hours there but if you have time you can spend the whole day. The layout is also good and interesting in some instances.

We loved walking through these gardens. They are beautifully landscaped with more than 4000 species of plants. They have a big collection of orchids too. The cannon ball tree was very fascinating. One can easily spend a couple of hours here without getting bored. But you have to be prepared to walk. The gardens are spread over a huge area.

I am not usually a botanical gardens fan, but our innkeeper and many guide books recommended this, so we decided to give it a try (especially since it was Monday and the Tea Museum was closed).  What a pleasant surprise!  The various avenues of palms are striking and you can enjoy many areas of shade as you explore the grounds.  The gift shop is excellent as well. You could easily spend hours here, but 90 minutes was enough for us. Enjoy!

Needless to say it was a massive spread of various plants and trees from around the world. Well maintained and clean with information on some of them which we found to be useful. Many tourists around due to its popularity though it could never get congested. A huge grassland in the middle gave our kids unimaginable space to play. Alongside was a cafe where I could only spot tourists,the locals were seated down on the grass with their modest meals. We sat around them too and couldn’t have enough of the fresh air that is usually missing in gulf counties. At 2000 LKR per adult it was worth our time and effort.

I have visited the garden as a teenager many times while living in Sri Lanka. After more than 30 years living abroad, I decided to take my teenagers to show this amazing place. It is very disappointing that they charge more than $40usd while the locals pay less than $1. Don’t get me wrong, this a very beautiful place but a steep cost for a family.
Tip - use a buggy for covering this in an hour. Very well maintained botanic garden. Entry fees is on the higher side but still highly recommended to visit

It is indeed a nice botanical garden to spend hours. The garden has wide space and plenty to enjoy. It well maintained. Different section of the garden fills heart with different types of feeling. A must visit place.

If you really want to do full justice to this place you need 2-3 hours as it's a huge botanical garden with variety of trees, flowers and birds. The garden is well maintained and there's also a buggy service if you don't want to walk the entire garden area. What i loved most is the orchid garden, the cactii garden, the Rose garden, lovely trees in various natural shapes and the way different plants are laid to bring our the beauty.

We had the choice of walking the gardens ourselves - or taking a tour on an electric buggy. We took the buggy - with some 6 other folk, and in a little over an hour saw as much as 3 hours of walking ( in the heat). The time saving was only one advantage - the buggy driver was an excellent guide that helped appreciate the various plants - and the historic connection of the gardens. The ride cost us LKR500 each.
The gardens are really worth the visit, I was shocked how much I enjoyed it. You need at least an hour

If you're visiting Kandy, spending a bit of time in the Botanical Garden is a must.  Reading about the history, seeing the beautiful displays, walking among the trees or even walking on the suspension bridge will interest all. We especially appreciated the flower displays along with the historical plaques commemorating the people who planted trees at the garden.  It's well worth the time.

Plan 2-3 hours for your stay. Otherwise you'll either have to hurry or can't see everything. Can recommend the gift shop. The selection is quite good and the prices are low (e.g. 100-200 RS for a magnet).

In Royal Botanical Gardens, you can see another view of Sydney Opera and Sydney Bridge. The view is good, air is flash, you can see sydney people relax life style. Also, Mrs Macquarie’s Chair is in it and worth to see.

May be we were just unlucky, but almost none of the flowers were blooming at that time + they are making some renovations, so the little lake was empty, covered in mud with lots of workers, rose garden leafless and empty, the map was outdated, some roads and items were not marked there. Only the trees are gorgeous and impressive. But, surely, its not worth spending LKR 2,000 per person.

This is a beautiful garden and a welcome haven from the busy centre of Kandy. There are so many interesting and unusual plants and it is a real joy to wander around for a few hours - I definitely recommend visiting if you are in or near Kandy. The photos on here and elsewhere online didn’t really do it justice, it is more impressive in real life!

Located about 10-15 kms away from kandy city. Its a huge botanical garden thats been developing from the last 100 years or so. Its beautiful and its huge. U can just keep walking for hours. Theres so much to observe here. Though i have no idea about trees/plants, it was quite fascinating to see the variety of flora n fauna. The botanical garden is really well maintained.  I found d entrance fee of 2000 LKR for foreigners too much though. Thats a big hole in d pocket. So if ur ok to spend on d entrance ticket then it’s surely worth a visit. We spent an hour n half just enjoying d greenery n pleasant weather.

The glowing reviews of the Botanical Garden baffle me.  Yes, it’s beautifully laid out, but labeling is miserable.  Upon entry, paying the massive foreigners’ fee – as if we’re some sort of different animal from Sri Lankans – visitors are given a map with such tiny print that it’s almost impossible to see.  The roads/paths aren’t marked on the map, and there’s no indication of the location of the flora featured on the pages adjacent to the map.  Some plants are labeled; most are not.  And the labels are pretty useless.  A large plot of dahlias, for example, are simply described as dahlias, no indication of the specific cross or the name of each plant.  It’s even worse in the orchid house, where the labels that would indicate the cross of the orchids, even the species name, are neatly hidden, and visitors are specifically admonished not to touch the plant labels.  So in the end the Botanical Garden offers a lovely stroll in an otherwise crowded city, but informative it most certainly is not.
We felt like we were in paradise. This garden is simply beautiful! Take your time to walk around and take in the beauty of the trees, flowers, and all sort of plants. Enjoy the peacefulness!

We arrived at about 2 p m and our driver waited about 2 hours. We could have stayed longer. It was peaceful and relaxing. All plants and trees had explanation labels attached. There’s a cafe, toilets and a good souvenir shop. We could have stayed longer in this beautiful area. It closes at 6 p m with last visits at 5 p m.

Although my wife and are lovers of all things historical, occasionally we need to refresh the mind and relax. The Gardens were included on our tour itinerary and provided a welcome interlude from the intensity of the UNESCO sites. The origins of the Gardens date to 1371 and they were declared a Royal Garden during the reign of King Kirti Sri Rajasinghe between 1747 - 1780. The Gardens on their present site were established in 1821 and cover an area of 60ha. showcasing over 4,000 species. The informative guide map that we received on entry contained a detailed legend and history of the Gardens. We spent approx. three hours strolling the walkways and admiring the beauty of the flora and it's diversity. The Orchid House held a marvelous display and variety of exotic blooms. We enjoyed the Flower garden with many annuals and perennials in bloom. The Palm Avenues are spectacular and include Royal, Cabbage and  Palmyrah, not to be ignored and great for photos, especially the Coco de Mer of Seychelles notoriety. We saw some of the tallest grasses in the world, stands of bamboos on River Drive, including the giant bamboo of Burma. We enjoyed the Fernery, Spice Garden, Cacti and the Arboretum. Interesting plaques recognizing world leaders and renowned visitors who planted trees there. Lovely way to spend a morning and then adjourn to the pleasant café near the entrance.

I'm not a huge fan of gardens and so forth however I found the Botanical gardens really interesting, trees planted by various Presidents and Prime Ministers from round the world, some dating back to the 60s. Trees that are a hundred years old, lots of wildlife like kingfishers and monkeys. We would have stayed longer but we were running out of time. Worth a visit if you like this sort of thing.

One of the must visit destinations in Kandy. The garden is very big & needs enough time to get a good tour. There are hundreds types of plants & many trees were planted more than 100 years ago. They are really giving special care to the place. It’s very clean, neat & well maintained. The suspension bridge is having very nice view to the river. Nice photos could be taken on it. The garden is a very good destination for relaxation.

For tourist who have visited similar parks in other parts of the world can avoid this.  The entry fee of LKR 2,000 for foreigners is not at all justified.  Its a waste of time and energy.  The only impressive part was the Orchid collection which had a few beautiful flowers.  The part is anyways well laid out and well kept.  You will find a lot of local couples romancing at secluded placed. If you do not get time to visit this location or avoid, you do not loose out on anything..  This is a very personal opinion.  Travelers who have lot of free time and money can definitely spend time here.  May be impressive for tourist from places with sparse vegetation.

Lovely place to visit.  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that my partner, one of the worlds leading agricultural crop plant pathologists, was very keen to visit the wild relatives of modern crops area.  Unfortunately, although this area is on the map it has been removed.  Aside from that a lovely place to spend a few hours.  The suspension bridge is not for the feint hearted!

We spent hours in this garden and if I had more time, I'd stay much longer. I loved this garden. It must have been the biggest I have been to in all my travels. The huge trees were extra special because of the history and their age. It is nice to find something like this at the heart of the city. Aside from plants, there are many animals roaming the garden so watch your belongings in case there are monkeys. They usually would not bother you but it's better to be sure. Wear comfortable footwear and clothes so you can cover the whole grounds.
This is an excellent botanical garden here in Sri Lanka. The garden is well maintained.  A good place to go for a walk.

Our guide took us here - it is wonderful - sadly the rain was fierce and we went round in a golf cart so only were there for about 90 minutes - wonderful trees and plants and the orchid house was special -it would be great to walk and fully understand the background and history - really peaceful

We don't want to go home after we visited the Royal Botanic Gardens. She is very impressed by the color of the flowers in the garden. She can’t stop taking pictures of her with such a lovely place. I truly loved this place.

The garden is very big. You could spend half a day for sure just walking around. It's a really nice place to visit. Unfortunately we didn't had enough time available to see the whole garden. I think we saw about half and we still spent about 2 hours or even more in there. The price is about 11$ per person. it's a really nice place to see.
The gardens are well worth a visit! The orchid house is great and the gardens very peaceful. Expect to spend a good 4 or 5 hours exploring the beauty!
Nice place to spend a day. Better go when it is not too hot. A lot of things to do - can spend even whole day in there.

The gardens have many trees that were planted nearly 200 years ago and they are stunning. The walkways and general surrounds are peaceful and well interpreted. There are a number of fantastic vistas within the grounds. We noticed you could get a buggy to take you around, although we decided to walk. The variety of plants is amazing and numerous birds were seen. Bit disappointed with the orchid displays...needs to be curated and rearranged. But all in all a beautiful place to visit.

The gardens are really nice, well designed and have a really diverse range of plant species. It is a nice way to spend a few hours if the weather is good however it is expensive for foreigners. 2000Rs for non residents and only 100Rs for residents, it seems like a big disparity in fees. It would have been nice if there was more information displayed about the different species in the gardens too.

Around 6km to the west of Kandy.  Overall these gardens are somewhat tired and neglected.  We have visited a number of botanical gardens around the world including in the tropics and these are typically free to enter or the entry price is reasonable.  The entry price for foreigners at Peradeniya is LKR2,000 per person, which is not far off what you would pay for far superior gardens in Europe.  I have no problem with foreigners being charged more than locals but the price charged should be reasonable and it would be good to see the money generated being invested in the site.

Hi, Its located very hill country close to Kandy city. 100Km far from airport and nearly 3 hours direct driving. The large botanical garden with real relaxing with enjoyable visit. More Eco hotels,star class hotels , restaurants and shopping , religious and many more activities near was their.Half day can spend better in morning & evening . Also  Temple of Tooth ,Pinnawala Elipahant Orphanage & Kadugannawa crossing in additional location to cover same tour. Thanks.

One of the main attractions in Kandy.  Entrance fees are 2000 Rps per person. If, like us your time is more limited you can hire a golf buggy for another 2000 Rps (although unfortunately you can't drive it yourself!!).  The guide will point out trees planted by various celebrities and royalty.  Although, I don't think this does the gardens justice and, in retrospect, would have preferred to wander through the pathways and enjoy them at a more sedate pace. As well as all the interesting trees, plants and orchids you can see monkeys and fruit bats.
Beautiful place where you can choose to take your time and walk around or you can go on the mini buses and get off at whatever stops you want. Very nice if you have a spare hour or two.

A quiet spot in Kandy, with hundreds of plants, trees ... and monkeys. Many Orchids in gorgeous colours. A great way to spend time is a slow stroll through the entire grounds. Nice to find a seat and just enjoy the beauty and quiet. Another must-do when in Kandy.

Beautiful gardens, apart from amazing plants there are also monkeys and gigantic bats there! We spent about 3 hours wandering around but it'd be easy to spend an entire day there if one has the time. The entry fee is 2000 rupees for an adult and 1200 for a student and they honour student's cards from all over the world.
Beautiful gardens loved the orchids a truely peaceful place to spend some time . A lot of shady places to get out of the hot sun .

These gardens are well presented and a must see in Kandy.  From the established trees and palm walks to various hot houses and green houses displaying orchids, cacti, flowering plants and many others o the trees full of resting fruit bats it’s a great way to fill in a few hours. The gift shop at the end also has a good range of reasonably priced items for those that like to shop. Just be sure to take a hat and sunscreen.

We enjoyed these gardens, as keen gardeners we found the gardens absolutely beautiful, I wish my garden could look as good as this! They give you a map, we still didn't manage to see it all. A lot of information on the different sort of trees and plants. The cactus/succulent house wasn't that impressive. It cost 1500 rs each to get in, worth a visit if you're in to plants.

Well worth a visit.  Huge garden to wander around and admire the vast and varied trees and plants in the garden all of which are well maintained.  Particularly impressed by the orchid house.  Added bonus are the monkeys and bats to add life to the garden.
These extensive gardens provide lush lawns on which children play, heaven in a crowded city. The maintenance and layout are quite good, but the plants and trees are not labeled which is a shame.
The botanical garden is vast and its is well maintained. It has separate areas for each of the type of plants/trees. We liked the Orchids the best. Enjoyed the visit here.

this botanical garden is said to be the garden used by the last king of kandy to meet his queen and stroll which was later improved by the British. a highlight of this garden is the orchid museum which has many varieties of orchid flowers.

Botanical Garden area is vast about 60ha and various types of tress, plants are there. Orchid, Herbal, flower, etc are in separate wings. Entrance for foreigners is LKR2000. Big lawn, tress in rows, Double coconut are speciality of this garden. Garden is well maintained and battery car facility is available to visit entire garden.

Loved our visit here especially seeing the bats hanging from the tress in one area of the gardens. Gardens are extremely well kept and beautiful to see especially the orchid house. Lots of walking to cover the vast area so recommend taking a bottle of water with you.

We easily got a tuk tuk from our hotel to take us to the gardens. Entry fee is about $15 CDN each person. There is a coffee/gift shop at what is the entrance and the exit area. Public washrooms, which are very clean, are at the entrance and throughout the gardens. Can easily cover the gardens in 3 hours or less depending on what you wish to see and how fast you walk. Well maintained and a treat for any nature lover. We also saw a troop of monkeys and many beautiful birds.

This place really is a gem and oh so beautiful but again foreigners will pay for the fact that they are foreigners. Effective August, 5 (we visited on the 6th🙈) the entrance fee was increased to 2000 Rupies. Still this place is worth a visit. Make sure to bring some time and enjoy the beauty of the park. There is lots to see and also enough spaces to rest. If this is not convincing you, just take a look at the pictures.
When you are in Kandy, you should definitely visit the gardens. You can easily spend a couple of hours there and see the amazing collection of trees, plants, etc. The kids also loved it!

It is unbelievable unless u read the pamphalet and check the dates...it is about 600+ years old garden and still maintained so well. Though they have Holf carts to take you around on nominal charges but the best way to explore this garden is buy walking around. Its not even difficult as there are benches arou d everywhere to sit and relax when u get tired. The river and the shaky bridge on it is really a great attraction in the park. A must visit site when in Srilanka.

Its is a huge botanical garden in the middle of Kandy city. Those with an inclination towards plant studies will have a great time exploring the garden as it has a lot of variety of plantation. We loved the greenery and beautiful flower garden. To my surprise we have seen a double coconut tree inside the garden and same dried one is for display in a museum inside premises. You can spend entire day if you wish to in a calm and beautiful garden. Please note it has an entry fee. I'll suggest to improve on the direction maps so people can explore their interest due to limited time being a tourist.

We loved exploring the beautiful grounds of the garden and only wish we'd had longer there. We arrived mid afternoon with our young children who adored the space to runaround and explore. They spent time looking at the different flora and fauna and admiring sights and sounds of the birds and numerous bats. We had been told there was a chance of seeing monkeys but were overwhelmed to observe them closely on the suspension ('dancing bridge'). We had a truly fabulous time visiting and would recommend it to everyone.

Really enjoyed this garden. Reasonable entry fee, large estate with well maintained gardens. Easy to navigate around either walking or with golf buggy and guide. Our boys 7yr & 9yr loved running around and down the end of the garden on the suspension bridge sat a couple of cheeky monkeys. The cafeteria was a pleasant surprise of tasty menue with good prices. Recommend a stop at this garden.

Actually "Kandy" sounds so much nicer than it is, BUT: on our second day we visited the botanical garden and it was far beyond our expections. Its a huge areal to plan at least 3 hours for the visit. Surprised by amazing garden planning and well cared... One of the best botanical gardens I ever visited.

My wife and myself are currently holidaying in Sri Lanka and this afternoon we visited the lovely Royal Botanical Gardens of Peradeniya in Kandy. After paying our SLR 1,500 (£7 approx) non-resident adult entrance fees, we spent a couple of hours exploring the extensive Gardens which will shortly (2021) be celebrating their 200th Anniversary. When I say extensive, we barely scratched the service but still had time to visit the impressive Orchard House. I also much enjoyed - particularly, as many of these had involved various members of the British Royal Family - seeing the number of trees planted by VIPs over the years. My personal highlight, however, was not Botanical by nature but seeing the literally thousands of Fruit Bats (Flying Foxes) that were certainly making their presence felt! All in all, a most enjoyable visit to what - by any standards - are first-rate Botanical Gardens.

the staff working at the ticket counter were extremely rude and unhelpful to us, arguing with us over the price of a ticket for my wife, who holds Residence visa in Sri Lanka, demanding for us to change our local tickets for tourist. would not return here.

We went back and forth on whether to stop here on our way into Kandy, since we only had one night in the city and it's pretty hot to walk around the gardens in the middle of the day. In the end we did stop, and we're very glad we did. You don't need that long in Kandy, and Peradeniya was certainly more interesting than anything in Kandy. It takes 2 or 3 hours to wander around. There's a lot of great plants and trees, but also birds and a large number of bats towards the back of the gardens.

It's located at a distance of about 30km from Kandy. I spent well over 3 hours in the gardens and absolutely enjoyed it. Its home to many native plants of Sri Lanka and the entire place is clean and very well looked after.

The garden includes many species of plants, This garden is home to trees from every corner of the tropical atmosphere.it's a massive garden and would take few hours for site seen. electric buggies were available, inside the garden average price cafeteria serving Western and Sri Lankan food for hungry tunnies. washroom facilities were available in many locations,  if you want to purchase plants, there is a plant centre near to the main gate ( Open at 0830 ). Barista and Laksala anchored near to exit.dont missed this man-made piece of art, it is a haven in the haven.
WOW. What a place. Beauty everywhere. Superb arrangements. Nice walking experience. Bridge is a little bit adventurous too. Very soothing. We luckily had a very good weather as well.

The botanical gardens could be a whole day's trip! There is so much to see and so many trails to walk (a map is a must!) There was this cool section where there were at least 100 bats hanging from the trees and I found it neat. There's also an old suspension bridge you can cross, but I wasn't brave enough to attempt it. I spent 2 hours walking around and I don't think I even saw half of it. The gift shop also has really good quality items! If you haven't done your gift shopping and you're at the gardens, do a bit there and save yourself the headache. I found some of the same items from the gift shop at other places and the quality wasn't as good.

this mammoth garden houses thousands of plant species and is well known for its collection of orchids.this garden is so large that you need atleast 3 to 4 hours to explore,keeping this in mind they have kept golf carts for internal travelling at a charge.the ticket to the royal botanical garden is 1000 lkr per adult.

The Botanical Gardens is located near the city and it dates back to 1371! It is on sprawling grounds and there are many beautiful tall palms to be found. We also chanced upon a section of the Garden where thousands of bats were hanging off the tree branches in broad daylight. Quite a sight. It was cooling in May and pleasant to walk around even at mid-day. The only negative is that the ticket is priced quite steeply at 1500 rupees for tourists.

Trees planted over one hundred years ago and many marked with who planted them and when. My favorite was the tree planted by the last Czar of Russia. Beautiful roads lined with various palms.  Exotic trees of great beauty. The most wonderful to me was the orchid house.  Well versed guides who drive you by electric carts.

The garden was very large and nice to walk through.  It wasn't as well kept as others I've seen, and not quite as lush, but if you like botanical gardens, you won't want to miss this one.  The plant house and orchid house are small, but have nice varieties.  There is a small suspension bridge towards the back that goes over the river.  It is nice to walk out on it and take a photo.  There are also a couple lanes with palm trees on either side and they make a nice photo opportunity if you can squeeze in between the girls making duck lips and taking Instagram shots.  There is also a large bougainvillea you can sit under and it makes a nice photo too.
These gardens are fabulous, beautifully laid out and well kept. Wonderful variety of plants, and saw monkeys playing in the giant bamboo. Well worth the visit. Quiet and peaceful.

Royal Botanical Gardens are beautiful place with huge botanical diversity. You can walk along the paths here and admire different species of plants. This gardens have a large area so you can spend much time in this place and it isn't boring. Inside the gardens is really calm, you can relax, take a breathe and stay away from the noise of the city. Highly recommend!

Make sure you have set aside at least two hours - there is a lot to see and considerable ground to cover.  A guide is not essential and though you will see sights familiar from home there are also exceptionally rare plants and flowers, all in perfect condition and set against majestic lawns and avenues of elegant palms.  There is a photo opportunity at every juncture.  Simply stunning and well worth the modest entrance fee.

These gardens are a treasure trove of tropical plants and history. They are beautifully set out and designed. The feature for many is the orchid house where some amazing orchids are on display. The avenues of trees, the lawn areas and flowering garden beds add to the general ambiance of peace and tranquility. Not to be missed in your visit to the Kandy area.
Her you can have a relaxed walk and see nice trees, plants but also bats and monkeys. There were many school children at the entrance but in the park there was sufficient space so it was not crowded
This is a beautiful place to have a walk. It`s not that full of tourists and is kinda quaiet to enjoy a nice day.

Well-maintained park, nice flora (plants / trees / flowers) with some cute fauna around. It's pretty and spacious, and nice for a walk on a fine day, but nothing too special, if you compare it with all the other botanical gardens that lots of countries also have. Or maybe the hoards of flying foxes around are pretty special, if you ask me. They were all flying around in the skies, looking for a spot to rest amongst the tall trees. I'm not sure if that's a seasonal sight, but I saw them when I visited in March. However for them to be collecting entrance fees for it seems a bit of a money-sucking move. If I were to do away with any humility here, you're welcome to visit my country's botanical gardens. Singapore's Botanic Gardens is bigger, prettier, UNESCO-listed, and free to enter. Just sayin'.

Went for a afternoon to this place, we were lucky as our tour guide got us a buggy which was good as the gardens are huge, there are so many different species of tree which have been donated from other countries, we found it so interesting, the orchid house is amazing so many different types in the hot house, the monkeys and fruit bats in the trees, not sure how long it would take to walk round but in the bug took over a hour.
we went to the garden in the morning,very nice,so many attractive flowers had bloomed,mind relaxing place,
The garden is impressive due to its size and diversity of the plants and in particular the tree-vellum fold. Definitely a place to relax and to be amazed.

The Botanical Gardens were very impressive in terms of content and scope.  A lovely way to spend a morning or afternoon.  Lovely bedding, impressive hot houses, especially the Orchid House and the Plant Room.  Everything was beautifully manicured.  Watch out for the giant palms and the giant bats!  Take your camera!

DO NOT MISS IT. It's absolutely beautiful and everyone will find something they like. Planes, trees, orchids, birds, bats by thousands and playful monkeys. It's fresh on a hot day, and oh so quiet. No honking or noisy tuktuk. It's a haven of piece in a busy town.

This was a pleasant way to spend a couple of hours and enjoy a good walk, but go earlier in the day before the heat becomes oppressive (it opens at 8 I think). As botanical gardens go, it was interesting and extremely well established. However, if you’re comparing it to Singapore, you will probably leave somewhat disappointed (especially with regard to the orchids). At LKR 1500 per person entry (approx AUD 12), it’s quite expensive by Sri Lankan standards.

Must visit place do take Electric car as lot of walk is involved as Shuttle is also available at good price but you have to wait for a long for availability ...and then we found wow... suspension bridge..orchid houses..flower garden.. etc
Good variety of flora. Entrance fees on a higher side 1500 LKR otherwise worth visiting and great place to visit especially in the afternoons.
We love nature and taking a walk, but the Royal Botanical Garden is a 5* experience. Words don’t describe well, so see pictures

The Royal Botanical Gardens in Peradeniya, Sri Lanka is not to be missed.  It is a beautiful place!  The trees and flowers are amazing.  It is so well cared for.  The birds are everywhere and are adding to the peacefulness by all their singing.

The way the gardens are done up is spectacular. Went with children so we hired a buggy and went around. Amazing landscape and beautiful scenery to be seen. Amazing to see so many orchids in the orchid house

Wide variety of plants and trees often famous for the dignitaries who planted them.  Good selection of orchids in the hothouse. Long periods of walking but there is a mini train that works as a hop on/ hop off bus.

A wide range of plants many of which have been planted by dignitaries from all over the world. The orchids are spectacular. The whole area is well kept and is a great place to spend a relaxing afternoon.
A very nice place to visit for an interesting and relaxing few hours. Great cafe. Hot house was wet and a good place to cool down.

The rain didn’t spoilt our visit here, when we spent a few hours in these beautiful botanical gardens. Impressive orchids and awe inspiring trees and flowers. So many gardeners keep this place immaculate. But I will never forget the hundreds of huge fruit bats hanging in the trees! When they took to flight ... it was scary!

The Botanical Gardens are definitely one of the highlights of a stay in Kandy.   If you are short of time take a 1 hour tour in a golf buggy with a local guide (1000 rupees) The guy we had was incredibly knowledgeable and showed us all sorts of plants and birds that we would have probably missed by just walking around on our own.   The fruit bats high up in the tree tops are fascinating.  Many of the wonderful trees have been planted by visiting dignitaries and our guide knew the date everyone was planted.

This was by far the highlight of our stay in Kandy. The gardens are stunning and there are so many plants and trees to take in. We enjoyed watching the fruit bats hanging from the trees. If you don’t have much time I would recommend prioritising the gardens.
The gardens are huge, so there was a lot of lovely spaces to walk around and see. There were also these huge bats which were pretty cool.

We visited the Botanical gardens in Kandy yesterday morning. We hired the golf buggy for one hour and were taken around the gardens by a guide who was very informative. We stopped and looked whenever we wanted to which was good. One of our group walked around but couldn't see all the gardens in that time therefore missed out on certain parts of the garden. We were short on time and apparently you need four hours to walk around the whole gardens. They are certainly worth a look at even if you don't have four hours. There is also a bus which takes about ten people.

Located in Peradeniya, just 5.5km to the west of the city of Kandy and is renowned for its collection of orchids. The garden is home to more than 4000 species of plants, spices, medicinal plants and palm trees. You can explore the grounds on foot, however, if you’re feeling tired, or potentially lazy, golf carts can be rented. It costs 1500 LKR/person to enter the gardens. A perfect place to relax and take some great pictures, we spent about 2 hours here and went early in the morning to avoid crowds of people.

This garden serves as both a leisure park and a biological resource. It is popular but huge. It is located a short distance out of Kandy but travel is slow. It is largely open but there are areas of shade.  Plants are largely well labelled.  A good map is provided.  Polythene is not permitted Th Royal Palm walk is splendid but there are many other interesting features. The orchid house is interesting and colourful. Dont miss the Javanese figs with their huge roots. Dont miss the numerous fruit bats in the northern area.  There is quite a lot of birdlife too.

A visit to the Botanical Gardens should be at the top of your To Do list here in Kandy.  It’s worthwhile paying for a buggy ride around the Gardens as there is much to see and the guide will point out many things you might otherwise miss.  It’s also hot, so the breeze as you drive is refreshing.
